awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites: Type I - University of Montana I-Corps Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This project from the University of Montana (UM) creates an NSF I-Corps Site at this institution. Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

The UM Site promotes commercialization of STEM research and innovation throughout the campus community. It capitalizs on the success of the Blackstone LaunchPad (BLP-UM) in fostering an entrepreneurial ecosystem at UM and the entrepreneurial  community in Montana. 

This project is a collaborative effort between BLP-UM and faculty in the Colleges of Business, Humanities and Sciences, Health Professions and Biomedical Sciences, and Office of Research. It leverages existing relationships and expertise to establish a program that facilitates growth of STEM-related startups. The UM I-Corps Site has five key objectives: expand STEM participation in entrepreneurship and build entrepreneurial skills amongst students, postdocs, staff, and faculty at UM; increase participation of women, Native Americans, and other groups underrepresented in both STEM fields and entrepreneurship; increase commercialization success of STEM innovation at UM; generate strong STEM teams that are well-prepared for National I-Corps training; and develop and assess programming that fosters an entrepreneurial ecosystem in a rural setting. These objectives are achieved through targeted outreach and recruitment, education and training, leveraging a network of support for Entrepreneurial Teams, and project evaluation and participant tracking.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The University of Montana I-Corps Site program (2018–2024) has made significant contributions to advancing STEM innovation and commercialization while emphasizing diversity and inclusion. The program’s primary goal was to accelerate and support teams with entrepreneurial and STEM-based innovation ideas poised for commercialization. Over six years, we successfully conducted 27 regional cohorts, engaging 92 teams and 178 participants. These cohorts were delivered in a hybrid format, combining in-person sessions with virtual meetings to enhance accessibility, ultimately boosting participation across STEM departments and the local community.

Intellectual Merit:

The program has advanced knowledge in STEM commercialization by equipping participants with essential entrepreneurial tools like customer discovery and lean canvas methodologies. Each team was required to conduct at least 15 customer interviews, helping participants assess the market feasibility of their innovations. As a result, teams either refined their commercialization strategies or pivoted based on the insights they gained. The program has led to the successful development of new entrepreneurial skills, with many teams continuing to explore market applications for their ideas. Notably, one regional team advanced to the I-Corps National program in 2020, further validating the effectiveness of our regional efforts.

Broader Impacts:

The I-Corps program has made a substantial societal impact through its focus on diversity, job creation, and providing sustainable solutions. Of the 178 participants, 66% were female and 11% were Indigenous, reflecting the University of Montana’s proactive commitment to enhancing diversity in STEM and entrepreneurship. This focus has empowered underrepresented groups by providing them with opportunities to explore and develop their innovative ideas. In partnership with Montana Tribal and Technical Colleges, we expanded our reach and provided regional I-Corps training to more communities.

Key societal benefits include:

  • Empowering Underrepresented Groups: A diverse range of participants, including women and Indigenous innovators, are actively advancing their ideas and contributing to the Montana entrepreneurial landscape.
  • Economic Growth and Job Creation: Many teams have continued their customer discovery and venture development efforts, laying the groundwork for future startups that will contribute to local economies.
  • Sustainable Solutions: Several projects focused on solving local challenges related to healthcare, the environment, and education, aiming to improve the quality of life in Montana’s rural and tribal communities.
  • Entrepreneurial Mindset: The program instilled entrepreneurial thinking among participants, fostering resilience, innovation, and leadership skills that transcend STEM and can be applied across various sectors.

Professional Development:

Participants gained invaluable professional development opportunities by attending additional conferences, meetings, and trade shows, where they expanded their customer discovery efforts and networked with industry professionals. This exposure further enriched their entrepreneurial experience and helped them refine their innovations.

Impact on Human Resources and Teaching:

The program has developed the entrepreneurial skills of STEM faculty, researchers, local entrepreneurs, and students, with many participants likely to pursue their innovative ideas beyond the cohort. Additionally, we successfully trained a new I-Corps instructor, allowing us to expand future cohort offerings and broaden the program's reach.

Future Prospects:

In 2024, the University of Montana joined the Great Plains I-Corps Hub, enabling collaboration with institutions in North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska, and Wyoming. This new partnership will strengthen outreach efforts and provide additional training opportunities, further enriching the entrepreneurial ecosystem in the region.

Overall, the University of Montana I-Corps Site program has successfully advanced STEM innovation,  promoted diversity, and created opportunities for economic and societal growth, positioning our region as a hub for future commercialization and entrepreneurial success.

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2024
Modified by: Paul Gladen
